title: Do big companies actually look at customer feedback? Does the feedback go to the developers? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think this is a great question, and I certainly have some unique perspective here having processed more than 100,000unique customer reviews over the years. There are lots of great answers here from technology companies. But I have found that technology companies are usually very progressive in all areas, including customer service. There’s really two parts to this question. 1. Do big companies listen to customer feedback? Overwhelmingly the answer is NO. Depending on what study you look it you will see data proving that more than 70% of companies ignore customer feedback. You don’t have to look past companies like Comcast who just tripled the size of their complaint department to attempt to solve this problem. The problem is the lack of choice.    Most “big companies” have a monopoly in their space. Don’t like AT&T wireless or Verizon customer service? Good luck finding a national telecom provider who will listen. 2. Do big technology companies listen to feedback? Yes.  Technology companies have to process feedback. That’s why companies like Salesforce.com (product) and Zendesk (company) are now billion dollar companies. If technology companies don’t process feedback and provide excellent customer service, the lose business almost instantly.    So really, they are forced to listen or they will never survive. If they aren't opening tickets in a CRM and closing them fast, customers will go somewhere else. It is really only a matter of time before all companies are held to the same high standard, but for now we live in a world of two types of customer service.

For consumer products, they may or may not and it is likely that you will never know.  I am not sure what you are looking for or if you are just curious.   Although companies don't have wrong intentions, in most cases, customer service takes care of many problems before developers know about it.   In Singapore, the fastfood submarine chains assemble the sandwiches any which way.  I used to often find parts of the sandwich with wamed up meat (BMT) and no condiments.  I tried complaining to the local company.  They kept insisting that I share the store location - I didn't do that, since it wasn't a store issue.  I then complained to the main US store.  I was feeling really smart when they replied promptly that they were very sorry and they would address the problem immediately.  A few days later, the same local manager who had contacted me earlier, called and asked me to share the store where I found the problem. A friend of mine had problems with the Hilton.  He was a regular customer.  They couldn't do anything meaningful to address his problem.  He moved to another hotel chain. I wrote about some of these issues in an article: Explaining Testing to Mom - Ministry of Testing - which links to a presentation: Page on ministryoftesting.com

In our discussion there are some clearly expressed statements that big companies: don't look at the feedback and hence don't consider it; look at the feedback and don't consider it;don't look at the feedback but they improve something, because the pressure coming from customers is constantly high (like big telecommunication companies. And I share Christine's point of view & experience - good luck in finding a national telecom provider who will listen);look at the feedback and consider it; additionally, as Daniel wrote, they get the feedback multichannel.I think that for some companies it can be difficult to apply the same standards as SME are obliged to, otherwise they loose their clients. A good case presented Len Markadian from Groove, How to Get Your Team to Act on Customer Feedback. Big companies have to pay critical attention to the clients, but the question with which kind of instruments and how fast do they react, remains open. I think, that it's when the question of company's size enters the discussion.

Yes we do. Every few weeks our Customer Service teams compiles some of the more common request and feedback we receive from users. This information is in turn distilled into the various teams responsible for different parts of the Spotify experience and get reviewed, debated and put on the roadmap to be implemented.  That said, explicit customer feedback is only one of the signals we look at. We also look at A/B tests, NPS scores amongst various segments, how people are actually using the product to determine how to best move forward on a specific topic.  When you get to the scale of Spotify  (or more so Facebook) you realize that there are many different types of users -- and people giving explicit vocal feedback does not always equal the sentiment across the entire userbase.

Yes they do. I know this because I carry out various analyses on consumer feedback for one of the world's largest consumer packaged goods companies in the world at my current job. The volume if comments is such that we receive 100,000 of them everyday. And that is from North America alone. All consumer feedback through letters, social media, emails, phone calls, etc is carefully collated and analyzed by using powerful business intelligence visualization tools. Dedicated consumer solutions managers then go through the generated reports, identifying emerging trends among consumer feedback and zeroing-in on the most widespread problems. It's a task such gargantuan companies take very seriously.

There is a tendency in software companies to take an "it'll do" approach. It is born out of what I see as the tyranny of very large numbers. Let me explain.I have a product. I cannot afford to continue playing with it to get it absolutely right. I decide to put it on the market at a low price to earn some money whilst I improve.On the first night I sell 500,000 copies and it goes berserk. It's all hands to the pump to get the product into the market place. Bug fixing tales a back seat. Then the team who developed one aspect of my product move on to new features and create the next release. New profit. Their old part of the package gets put to bed, bugs and all.In addition the potential upgrades of the consolidated  parts of the package generate less profit than new facilities. So they get lost.And so Microsoft Outlook still has bugs in it that were present on day one all those years ago, and obvious enhancements like shared name and address files are never delivered.So my answer to your questions is NO, not interested. We know what the bugs are, we aren't going to fix them and the money keeps rolling in.Until Vista rears it's ugly head and then you realise there is a step too far for any company which can take them down, big as they are.But it took a sledgehammer to get even the Vista message across and there are still MS employees who boast about the product.

I'm my experience most have a 'process' but not all know or care about the data.  Also, it's really hard to get an organisation to care about feedback and complaints if the organisation's employed don't give a shit.  Take BT for example. They have failed for five booked appointments now for an install I have been waiting for four months (and counting). They present a very disorganised and poor communicating business. Sometimes they even turn up to ask me if anything has happened.  The flawed systems automate to ensure no planning or preparation so engineers turn up to find they can't do their work.  Back office teams are faceless and act no better than robots (I'm sure robots could be developed to present more empathy).  Now I have 'the Chairman's office' involved I get regular updates to tell me they didn't turn up to meet me 2 days ago. They are none the wiser what is going on. They ensure me the complaints of no communication and failed appointments are sent to the senior managers. Yet no one cares about these complaints. No one calls me about them.  Professional businesses see complaints and feedback as valuable information and are grateful of the time customers take to feedback. They take the information received and act to resolve and make sure systems, processes, people and culture are improved so issues don't happen again.   I'm sure my order is on someone's spreadsheet somewhere negatively effecting someone's 'customer delight' target.

Absolutely! At Google, I've seen a select few comments from customer feedback being talked about at a TGIF, a company wide meeting held by founders every week. Customer feedback and customer satisfaction are taken quite seriously at Google. Not listening to what your customers are saying about your products is a recipe for a disaster, and no company is an exception to this, not even Google/ Facebook/ Microsoft.

In general, companies are struggling with feedback. Feedback management is one of most company's pain point due to the channels it comes from and the different nature of feedback. Most companies do listen to feedback, especially when the content is repetitive. You have to note that people look at products and services differently, and my use case may be the only use case on the market - they won't make the changes I ask. But if people are asking for the same thing repetitively, they'll listen. And each feedback here counts. I'd like to share something I read a few months ago, and is directly linked to the use of feedback (have no affiliation with the writer nor the publishing company): From 0 to $1B - Slack's Founder Shares Their Epic Launch Strategy

Definitely! Customer feedback is all about being human, and non-human companies are constantly failing. Companies still struggle communicating with employees (and customers, for that matter). To make it easier I came up with the "mirror principle": Worth a read if you're interested in the idea: Customer Feedback is Your Company's Mirror Have you thought about why we use mirrors? They are, honest, instant, immediate, transparent. This is what true feedback should look like in business.

Hi, I´m looking this from the other side as I´m the guy that offers the scalable services to collect and analyze the feedback but I can assure that they do. To keep the story short, in my opinnion big companies are even better at this than their small competition in contrary to common beliefs. The key is always to attach the feedback (or any other customer data what so ever) to actionable insights automatically that now e.g. development can use as guidelines. Hope this helped! If you want more info, go check How to get started with your CX measurement in multichannel  and our blog! ;)  -Jaakko

Every company, big or small, HAS to look at customer feedback. Customers buy/use the services offered by companies, their experience / comments / feedback is of utmost importance. And to give a short answer to the question "does the feedback go to the developers", indirectly yes. But not directly, of course, otherwise it would be completely unmanageable. Customers' feedback / complaints / comments highly influence development sprints and overall product evolution.

Yes, they do. Some internal experiences vary from company to company. For example, at a large company, they will have a customer service/experience team look at the data. At more forward thinking companies their executive team will review it together. Looking at the feedback is the easier part. Habitually creating operational improvement plans based on the feedback is what exceptional companies do. -Michel www.michelfalcon.com

Yes they do… 90% of the companies are doing it now, as the consciousness is increasing towards data analytics, they are trying to analyze and come up with a better solution for the most problematic field… To be precise each and every feedback/review will be considered but number plays an important role here… u might be aware that majority wins… that's what happens the area or the concern with the most number will be taken action.

Absolutely.  It's called "white mail" and should be central source of free market research at the forefront of all product development. However mad something has made me, if I complain, I try to do it in a way that the person who designed the user experience can take my feedback and do something with it, apart from shoving it up his ****!   So be constructive and digital companies will listen, and their Agile methodology should allow them to act upon it in weeks, not months.

Yes. When I was at Microsoft, there were lots of resources dedicated to customer feedback. The developers obviously don't have time to be reading every single response, but as a whole the team knew what the issues were as collated and summarized from someone who did read them all.

It would be pretty short sighted not to, considering how the internet has changed everything and bad reviews are aplenty. That said, there's good feedback and there's....feedback. At QuickTapSurvey (Offline Survey & Data Collection App) we find that companies who invest in seeking customer feedback through various channels, including in-person surveys, build more loyalty rather than simple repurchasing.
yes they do, i have been a part of bank of america and we take our customer review seriously. It is one of the most important aspect of our annual review.
Yes of course it has become a very big business now a days and many companies do it on their own r they outsource to consulting companies
